Question:
What are UNION, MINUS and INTERSECT commands?
The UNION operator is used to combine the results of two tables while also removing duplicate entries.
The MINUS operator is used to return rows from the first query but not from the second query.
The INTERSECT operator is used to combine the results of both queries into a single row.

How To Use Bullet Points in Your Resume To Stand Out
Updated June 23, 2023

Since many employers only spend a few seconds looking at each resume to find qualified candidates, you want your resume to be as succinct as possible. You should choose a resume format that is easy to scan and makes your qualifications stand out to employers. Using bullet points to explain your work experience and skills is a great way to do this.

In this article, we explain how to effectively use bullet points in your resume.

Should you use bullet points for your resume?
Using bullet points in your resume is a great way to help employers notice your skills and qualifications that relate to the open role. You can use bullet points when you want to show your responsibilities and achievements for each of your previous jobs. Your skills section is also a great opportunity to use bullet points to organize them and make them easier to read.

To upload the template into Google Docs, go to File > Open > and select the correct downloaded file.

When can you use bullet points for your resume?
Include bullet points when you are using a chronological or combination resume. Both of these kinds of resumes focus on your previous work experiences. Bullet points are not as useful for a functional resume that focuses more on in-depth skills rather than experience.

Related: Top Resume Formats: Tips and Examples of 3 Common Resumes
How can you use bullet points for your resume?
You can use bullet points in the work experience section of your resume. This is the part of your resume where you list all of your previous jobs that are relevant to the job you're applying to. You should list your jobs in reverse chronological order, meaning your most to least recent jobs.

Under each job, include two to four bullet points that outline any accomplishments or duties that relate to the job you're applying to. Be specific about what you accomplished, referencing specific results and data.

You can also use bullet points under your volunteer experience to provide details about your positions and the work you did. Also, you can use bullet points to list your skills and achievements.

Related: 10 Resume Writing Tips To Help You Land a Position
Tips for using bullet points
Spend time crafting bullet points that show you are an experienced and qualified candidate. Here are some tips to get started:

Relate to the job.
Be brief.
Be specific.
List in order of importance.
Use simple bullet points.
Use interesting action verbs.
Relate to the job
When writing your bullet points, include accomplishments and job responsibilities that relate to the job you're applying to. If you find that some of your jobs don't relate, you may want to leave them out or try to reference similarities. One way to do this is by including soft skills used at that job that could also be used at the job you're applying to.

To save yourself time, make a master resume that lists all of your work experiences, education, volunteer experiences and skills. It can help you keep track of everything, and it's easy to pull from when making specific resumes. Since this master resume isn't specific to one job application, it may be a few pages long, which is fine since it's for your own use.

Related: How to Make a Resume (With Examples)

Be brief
Keep your bullet points brief by only including information that is absolutely necessary. Choose details that relate to the job you applied to and make you look accomplished and skilled in your field.

Be specific
Include specific details about who you worked with, what you did and why it was important. For instance, if you led a team of people, include how big your team was. Likewise, if you ran a successful ad campaign, share the specific data you collected, such as how many impressions you got. Numbers help employers have a better understanding of what exactly you accomplished.

Related: How To Write a Targeted Resume: Tips and Example

List in order of importance
Include the most important information in your first bullet point. Continue to list things in order of importance and relevance so they stand out the most to employers.

Related: How To Write Strong Bullet Points for Your Resume

Use simple bullet points
When choosing your bullet points, keep the formatting simple. Only use basic circles, squares or hyphens to keep your resume looking clean.

Related: Top Resume Formats: Tips and Examples of 3 Common Resumes

Use interesting action verbs
Start each bullet point with an action verb. Instead of using the same ones constantly, choose some more interesting action verbs that better describe exactly what you did in that role.

Here are a few interesting action verbs to use:

a.	Acquired
b.	Assessed
c.	Coordinated
d.	Formalized
e.	Launched
f.	Modified
g.	Orchestrated
h.	Spearheaded
i.	Sustained
j.	Transformed
k.	Yielded
Read more: Why Action Verbs Are Important for Resumes (With Examples)
See how your salary compares
Get personalized salary insights with the Indeed Salary Calculator
Examples of how to use bullets points for a resume
If you are applying for multiple jobs at once, you may have to write different variations of your resume to tailor each resume to each job. These examples will help you understand how many different ways you can write your bullet points.

Using bullet points for job descriptions
Here are three job descriptions with bullet points that you can review:

Orange Media Agency | Albany, New York
Administrative Assistant, July 2018–January 2020

Provided administrative support to senior executives to ensure smooth operations across the entire company
Spearheaded training initiatives for new hires which included writing a 150-page employee handbook, creating training documents and scheduling manager meetings
Composed daily reports for account executives and senior executives to help shareholders understand company goals and daily progress
University Marketing | Milwaukee, Wisconsin
Marketing Specialist, May 2016–September 2019

Launched a marketing campaign to get more students to attend the annual a cappella concert. Used social media, direct marketing and email marketing. Resulted in a 15% attendance increase from the previous year.
Developed and implemented communication and marketing pieces, including direct mail, emails, online content, student newsletters, press releases and other materials as needed.
Performed daily webmaster duties to ensure the university's website was up to date and accurate.
Dog Paws Palace | Athens, Georgia
Dog Handler, April 2017–December 2019

Managed up to 25 dogs at once, making sure dogs displayed appropriate behaviors
Oversaw the safety and comfort of all dogs in day care and boarding
Researched and implemented a new email system to streamline communications between the day care and clients, leading to higher customer retention and higher reported customer satisfaction
Administered the proper food and medications to each dog

Examples of Data Sets for Text Analysis and NLP Projects
CS 175, Fall 2022
The links below point to just a few of the many data sets for text analysis that you can find on the Web, and should help you in terms of finding data sets to work on for your projects. Note that these are just some examples of many publicly-available text datasets that are available - please feel free to use other datasets that you find (or create) beyond those listed below.

Text Classification and Sentiment Analysis
Multiple text classification datasets from NLP-progress
Multiple sentiment analysis datasets from NLP-progress
Yelp Data Set Challenge (8 million reviews of businesses from over 1 million users across 10 cities)
Kaggle Data Sets with text content (Kaggle is a company that hosts machine learning competitions)
Labeled Twitter data sets from (1) the SemEval 2018 Competition and (2) Sentiment 140 project
Amazon Product Review Data from UCSD. This is a very large and rich data set with review text, ratings, votes, product metdata, etc. The full dataset is extremely large - some of the smaller subsets provided may be better for class projects.
IMDB Moview Review Data with 50,000 movie reviews and binary sentiment labels
Well-known Movie review data for sentiment analysis, from Pang and Lee, Cornell
Product review data from Johns Hopkins University  (goal is to predict ratings on scale of 1 to 5)

Dialog/Conversation/Chatbots
A repository of large datasets for models of conversational response
A survey paper on data sets available for building data-driven dialogue systems
Amazon Topical Chat Dataset with accompanying research paper and blog post from Amazon.
ConvAI2 Competition Dataset
Multiple labeled dialog/chatbot datasets from NLP-progress
Cornell Movie-Dialogs Corpus
Transcripts from the TV series "The Office" (formatted for the R language)

Text Analysis Examples
There are two main text analysis techniques that you can use – text classification and text extraction. While they can be used individually, you’ll be able to get more detailed insights when you use them in unison.

Let's take a look at some examples of the most popular text analysis techniques.

Text classification
Sentiment analysis
Topic analysis
Language detection
Intent detection
Text extraction
Keyword extraction
Entity extraction
Text Classification
Text classification, also referred to as text tagging, is the practice of classifying text using pre-defined tags. There are many examples of text classification, but we’ll just touch upon some of the most popular methods used by businesses.

Sentiment Analysis
Sentiment analysis can automatically detect the emotional undertones embedded in customer reviews, survey responses, social media posts, and beyond, which helps organizations understand how their customers feel about their brand, product, or service.

Question: Here are tips to maximize your success in the Writing Test or achieve the highest score.
Answer:
1.Carefully analyse the task requirements.
2.Identify the purpose and audience.
3.Consider the tone and style required for the task Time Management: 
4.Allocate time wisely for Task 1 and Task 2. 
5.Stick to recommended time limits. 
6. Keep an eye on the clock throughout the test Structured Response:
7.Develop clear introductions, body paragraphs, and conclusions. 
8.Use effective paragraphing to enhance readability. 
9.Ensure a logical flow of ideas within paragraphs Cohesion and Flow: 
10.Utilize a range of linking words for coherence.
11.Employ transition phrases for smooth transitions between sentences and paragraphs. 
12.Ensure a clear and sequential progression of ideas Vocabulary Range: 
13.Showcase a diverse vocabulary to express ideas precisely. 
14.Avoid excessive repetition; use synonyms and varied expressions. 
15.Use domain-specific vocabulary when appropriate Grammar Precision: 
16.Focus on grammatical accuracy, including verb tenses and subject-verb agreement. 
17.Demonstrate a variety of sentence structures, including complex and compound sentences. 
18.Use punctuation effectively to enhance clarity Stay On Topic: 
19.Maintain a focused response, directly addressing the given question. 
20.Avoid unnecessary details or information that doesn't contribute to the main argument Practice Regularly: 
21.Practice under timed conditions to simulate exam situations. 
22.Explore a wide range of essay topics to adapt to different question types. 
23.Incorporate feedback from teachers or peers into your practice routine Review and Revise: 
24.Edit your essay for errors in spelling, grammar, and punctuation. 
25.Check for coherence and consistency in your writing style. 
26.Ensure your essay adheres to the specified word count Task 1 Tips (General Training): 
29.Adapt your tone and style according to the specified purpose (formal, semi-formal, or informal). 
30.Familiarize yourself with common letter writing formats Task 2 Tips: 
31.Clearly express your opinion in Task 2 essays. 
32.Support your arguments with relevant examples and details. 
33.Develop a strong thesis statement that outlines the main points of your essay Expressive Language: 
34.Strive for clarity and depth in your expression. 
35.Avoid overly complex sentences that may lead to confusion. 
36.Use descriptive language to paint a vivid picture when necessary Adaptability (General Training): 
37.Adjust your writing style to match the tone required for the specific task. 
38.Understand the nuances of formal, semi-formal, and informal language. Consistency in Practice.
39.Establish a consistent writing practice routine. 
40.Analyze and learn from your mistakes to improve over time.  
41.Focus on both strengths and weaknesses in your writing Task Response: 
42.Address all aspects of the task in your essay. 
43.Answer directly and avoid going off-topic. 
44.Be mindful of the balance between Task 1 and Task 2 in terms of time and effort Word Count: 
45.Stay within specified word limits for each task. 
46.Practice writing to different word count targets to adapt to varied requirements Task 2 Thesis Statement: 
47.Clearly state your position in the introduction. 
48.Outline the main arguments or points that will be discussed in your essay Developing Ideas: 
49.Support your points with relevant and specific examples. 
50.Provide a balanced perspective on the given topic Concluding Well: 
51.Summarize key points in the conclusion. 
52.Restate your position in a conclusive manner. 
53.Avoid introducing new information in the conclusion Audience Consideration: 
56.Keep in mind the examiner as your audience. 
57.Clarify complex ideas to ensure understanding. Avoiding Redundancy: 
58.Exclude unnecessary details that do not contribute to the main message. 
59.Eliminate repetitive phrases or redundant statements. Proofreading Skills: 
60.Sharpen proofreading abilities to catch errors. 
61.Read your essay aloud to identify areas of improvement. 
62.Double-check for spelling, grammar, and punctuation mistakes Handling Complex Topics: 
63.Break down complex ideas into manageable sections. 
64.Use clear and concise language to explain intricate subjects. 
65.Ensure that your explanations are easy to follow Consistency in Argumentation: 
66.Maintain a consistent line of argument throughout your essay. 
67.Ensure that each paragraph contributes to the overall coherence Avoiding Bias: 
68.Present a balanced view, especially in opinion essays. 
69.Acknowledge counterarguments and respond to them thoughtfully Paragraph Unity: 
70.Start each paragraph with a clear topic sentence. 
71.Ensure that all sentences in a paragraph contribute to the main idea Using Relevant Examples: 
72.Include specific examples to support your arguments. 
73.Ensure that examples are relevant to the given topic Logical Progression: 
74.Ensure a logical progression of ideas from one paragraph to the next. 
75.Use signposts to guide the reader through your essay. Sentence Variety: 
76.Demonstrate a variety of sentence structures. 
77.Avoid overly repetitive sentence patterns Introduction Impact: 
78.Craft an engaging introduction to capture the reader's attention. 
79.Clearly state your thesis or main argument in the introduction. Avoiding Cliches: 
80.Steer clear of overused phrases or clichés. 
81.Use fresh and original language to express ideas Understanding Graphs and Charts (Academic): 
82.Practice interpreting different types of graphs and charts. 
83.Highlight significant trends and variations Polishing Language: 
84.Use precise and vivid language to enhance descriptions. 
85.Avoid vague or ambiguous expressions. Checking Coherence: 
86.Ensure that there is a logical connection between paragraphs. 
87.Use cohesive devices effectively Parallel Structure: 
88.Maintain parallel structure in lists and comparisons. 
89.Ensure consistency in grammatical forms Handling Unfamiliar Topics: 
90.Familiarize yourself with a range of topics to handle the unexpected. 
91.Practice adapting your writing style to different subjects. Avoiding Overgeneralizations: 
92.Provide specific details rather than making broad generalizations. 
93.Support general statements with concrete examples Synthesizing Information: 
94.Synthesize information from different sources in Task 1 (Academic). 
95.Practice summarizing and paraphrasing. Task-Specific Vocabulary: 
96.Incorporate task-specific vocabulary when appropriate. 
97.Use terminology relevant to the given topic Managing Stress: 
98.Practice relaxation techniques to manage test anxiety. 
99.Stay calm and composed during the writing test. Building Confidence: 
100.Build confidence through consistent and targeted practice.
